## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I've been thinking about creating my own blockchain project, but I'm not sure where to start. What are some challenges that creators face when trying to bring their blockchain ideas to life?

**AI Assistant:**
Creators may face numerous challenges when trying to bring their blockchain ideas to life, including having to fork a Github repository, create an Amazon AWS or Droplet account, subscribe to centralized services, and set up an array of servers. Additionally, they may struggle with growing a community, getting listed on exchanges, building a wallet, creating infrastructure, finding help, and publishing their idea. It can be a daunting task, but there are ways to make it easier.

**User:**
That sounds overwhelming. What is the problem with the current process of creating a blockchain?

**AI Assistant:**
The current process of creating a blockchain can be challenging, time-consuming, and expensive. It often requires creators to rely on centralized solutions, jump through numerous hurdles, and deal with multiple different companies. This can be a barrier to entry for many people, and may prevent some ideas from being brought to life.

**User:**
That makes sense. What is the main issue with the traditional approach to creating a blockchain?

**AI Assistant:**
The main issue with the traditional approach to creating a blockchain is that it requires creators to rely on centralized solutions and jump through numerous hurdles, which can be a barrier to entry and prevent some ideas from being brought to life.

**User:**
Is there a better way to create a blockchain and bring ideas to life?

**AI Assistant:**
Yes, there are alternative approaches to creating a blockchain that can make it easier and more accessible for creators to bring their ideas to life. One such approach is Public Blockchains as a Service (PBaaS), which allows creators to focus on their ideas without having to worry about the underlying infrastructure. It's a more streamlined and efficient way to create a blockchain, and it can help level the playing field for creators.
What are some challenges that creators face when trying to bring their blockchain ideas to life?

Creators may face numerous challenges when trying to bring their blockchain ideas to life, including having to fork a Github repository, create an Amazon AWS or Droplet account, subscribe to centralized services, and set up an array of servers. Additionally, they may struggle with growing a community, getting listed on exchanges, building a wallet, creating infrastructure, finding help, and publishing their idea.

Title: Imagine You Had an Amazing Blockchain Idea
Article URL: https://medium.com/veruscoin/public-blockchains-as-a-service-36c858bcfe2f
Content:Imagine You Had an Amazing Blockchain IdeaOne so good, our world seems primitive without it. You can already see your coin flippening itself through the ranks, showing its immaculately crisp logo on hundreds of Youtube channels, and finally, plunging into the mainstream.
So, naturally, you search the internet for “How to make your own blockchain” to get started. Immediately, you are met with big, centralized, advertised corporate solutions sitting atop their money stacks on the front page of results. You keep scrolling. Smaller, cryptocurrency projects slowly fill your screen. One seems to stick out to you; it’s fancy website and pointy, triangular logo draw you to it’s instruction page. You read it, watch some videos, and get started, only to find that you’ll need to fork a Github repository, create an Amazon AWS account or Droplet account, subscribe to some centralized service, and set up an array of servers.
This may stop some people from moving on, but not you, you’re driven. You trudge through hours of your time, some of your money, and finally, it’s ready.
You’ve done it. Created a blockchain. Congratulations! You’ve finished the easiest part. What lies ahead includes months of growing a community, struggling with exchanges, building a wallet, creating infrastructure, finding help, publishing your idea, and becoming known. Hopefully, at the end of all this, you’ll have enough time, money, and motivation to actually start implementing your idea, but it’s easy to understand why we might not be seeing all of the potential we hear so much about.
It doesn’t have to be this way. Creators shouldn’t have to jump through numerous centralized hurdles, deal with multiple different companies, and ultimately rely on others to bring
./raw_text_input_medium/Imagine You Had an Amazing Blockchain Idea-2019-05-21 00:36:16

This can be a barrier to entry for many people, and may prevent some ideas from being brought to life.
